Dec 13, 2016

Bizarro Land — Trump’s Cabinet Picks

With each new Trump cabinet pick, I feel like I’m slipping deeper into some bizarro Alice in Wonderland land, where lyrics from Alanis Morrisette’s Ironic are on continuous loop. As far as I understand, this is where we are at — please correct me if I’m wrong (I’m really hoping that’s the case).

Note: I’m about to engage in some exasperated venting. If you would like intellectual analysis of the situation, you should perhaps look elsewhere.

Department of Justice: An Attorney General who failed to secure a judgeship in Alabama in 1986 because of racist comments. That’s right — Alabama. 1986. Racist Comments. I was in Alabama in 1990–4 years after he was accused of racism and felt like a naive, privileged Northern white girl who failed to comprehend the level of racism that still existed in our country until I visited Selma. I saw firsthand the segregated churches, schools and even YMCAs. And a girl my age unabashedly told me her uncle was in the KKK — like it was no big deal (my voice is rising to an incredulous pitch at this point). And yet — in 1986 — our President elect’s pick for Attorney General was found to be too racist in that severely racist place to be a judge (I apologize to all non-racist Alabamians, I know you exist). Unbelieveable. I’m not even going to touch his Senate record. Just ‘believe me’ when I tell you — if you care for civil liberties — you should be afraid.

Department of Education: A billionaire heiress/philanthropist for a Secretary who has no experience as an educator. Furthermore she has a history of supporting voucher programs that take money out of public schools and hand it over to private or charter schools — think education capitalist style. She seems to think parents can vote with their feet and support only the good schools, not the failing ones. Sounds great for the already educated, privileged class who can transport their kids to whatever school they wish. Not so great for parents who don’t have the time, resources or knowledge available to vote with their feet — their kids have to attend whatever school is most available — regardless of quality. Geesh. Talk about an education divide.

Department of Health and Human Services: Some of you may actually like this guy, or at least think you agree with his conservative agenda; unless you’re one of the 24,000,000 Americans benefitting from the Affordable Care Act (which he wants to repeal); one of the 53,800,000 Americans on Medicare (which he wants to privatize) or one of the 5,000,000 men, women and adolescents who receive sexual and reproductive health care, education and information from Planned Parenthood each year (which he wants to defund) — if you’re one of those 82.8 million Americans (roughly 1 in 4 — assuming no overlap) — then you should be afraid for the future of your health care. Very afraid. Just saying. You don’t have to believe me if you don’t want to.

Department of Transportation: I actually don’t have anything to say about this one. Not sure if she has transportation experience per say — but she does have experience running a major department. She was Labor Secretary under W. for 8 years, Director of the Peace Corps and CEO of United Way. Thoughts anyone? Need to defer to the rest of you here. Maybe not the best pick if your goal is to drain the swamp.

Department of Treasury: A Goldman Sachs insider who wants to repeal banking regulations to ease lending laws. Housing crisis 2.0 here we come? I don’t know. But I’m asking.

Department of Defense: Nothing but respect. As long as he can lead as a civilian and not a military commander (given that pesky 7 years-out rule). So far Transportation and Defense are the two Wonderland exceptions for me.

Department of Labor: I know there’s no law that says the Secretary of Labor actually has to support laborers. But, from my soapbox, it feels like opposing overtime and living wages is more than a couple of steps back.

Department of Housing and Urban Development: Here’s a neurosurgeon who said he wasn’t qualified to lead our Health Department, but he can lead our Housing Department? I’m just frankly confused.

Department of State: He’s probably smart. He probably has tons of international experience. He’s probably a good negotiator. But the business entanglements are killing me. One of State’s creeds is to promote our form of democracy — which includes anti-corrupt business practices. Not sure how we’ll be able to do that with Putin’s buddy and major oil representing us on the international stage. If hypocrisy could scream.

Department of Energy: A guy in charge of a department he once forgot…enough said.

That’s it. I have to stop. I’m making myself crazy. Oh wait — before I go — I need to give a shout-out to the Environmental Protection Agency Administrator whose website bio says he’s a leading advocate against the agenda of the agency he’s been named to lead. Oh boy.

It feels so melodramatic to say this. But the big question in my mind is, can our Republic survive this? Seriously.
